title: Things to know before complaining about 10 bans and Item Sets
body:
First, it was ***not even possible*** to implement 10 bans until the old legacy client that didnt support it was retired. People dont seem to understand this. The Legacy client ***did not support the new 10 ban system***. Now that it's finally being retired across all servers, they can ***just now*** implement it. Calm down. They weren't just holding back on us for no reason. 

Second, [Riot has already said the Item set creator will be back very soon](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/features/legacy-client-now-retired)

> FIRST, we've finally got a date for the return of the Item Set Creator Tool. We're now aiming to bring the feature (which lets you edit item sets from the client without using a third party tool) to the PBE with patch 7.10. Barring any problems, it will then come to live servers soon after. We'll update you in the patch notes if anything happens to delay the tool's release further. Check the FAQ below for more details.

***This was announced two weeks ago***

Everyone needs to chill out

replies.body:
I understand the Legacy client was limited, but it's frustrating that I went from getting a solid 50 to 55 FPS consistently to being thrown down to 24-30 FPS for the majority of the game (IE; Whenever I'm NOT in base). 

This new client is a good step forward, but in other aspects it is a large step backwards. It was definitely rushed, and it definitely needed more time before it was ready to completely replace the legacy client

You need to check these two boxes

http://imgur.com/uRcVWp9

If you still have in game issues after that, it has absolutely nothing to do with the client

I have both of those checked and in game my FPS is still averaging 35-40 when it's good, usually dropping into the low teens during larger fights.

It's definitely the client's issue, as well, because my computer run much more intensive games at full 60 FPS no problem.
Its not. How could it ***possibly*** be the client ***when the client closes during the match?***

I'm dumb.

That said, it has *something* to do with the new client, if only indirectly because the FPS drop only happened after the switch, and like I said it a league thing, not my computer.

I don't have a good explanation for it (maybe the client doesn't correctly close out? idk) but it's an issue nonetheless.
Windows 10 updates have been notorious for messing with fps in games.
Not that either, this *just* started, haven't had and OS updates that would change anything, and like I said, *just* league is having issues now.

Strange..

If I can run league on a macbook air better then you can...

Well

Sucks.
Maybe your hardware in the computer is just getting old and slowing down.
it's only 3 years old for the oldest stuff in it, everything else is fine. I still load faster than most other players, and have better ping and internet, fps is just lousy.
Try turning off xbox game DVR
what are your specs?

There shouldn't be any in-game differences resulting from the client change over (as they both result in the same game), and there pretty much 100% shouldn't be if you have it set to close the client when the game is running (if anything, new client should be slightly faster since you can have the client closed while in-game, in the old one I don't think that option existed). The client changes could cause problems when navigating the menus (loot, store, etc.) and more crucially in champ select so there are reasons to complain if you're accidentally dodging due to the client impacting your ability to pick/ban, but once you load into the game, it's literally the same independent of client.

There may have been other issues that showed up around the same time as the new client which people blame on the client despite being unrelated, so that might give the new client a worse rap than it actually deserves. (Theres probably also a variety of people who should be using low spec mode, but don't realise it even exists.)

Be it for high end or low end machines, the new client is poorly optimized and slowing down hardware because it's backround stuff is either too much, or badly handled.

EDIT: And this is the League Client and Riot we're talking about, this would hardly be the first time they tried to make something that was obsolete, better, and only made the situation worse for a large number of people.

When you check the second box, the client will *literally* quit while the game is running. The process isn't even running on your computer. You can't improve performance any more than that. If there were fps issues that popped up recently, it was the result of an in-game change, not the client.

> It was definitely rushed, and it definitely needed more time before it was ready to completely replace the legacy client

Are you serious?
It's literally been months when Riot started updating the client and then the gradual testing/server roll-out has been done in phases to ensure the testing could be controlled and any major problems intercepted before they affect so many players. Riot covered their basses pretty heavily with this one and this is one of the reasons why the client update has been this slow to begin with.

And it's understandable that it was, updating the client is no small task.
PSA : Item Sets are enabled on the PBE right now, so we might get them next patch.
http://25.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_mdt6qpDEJk1rby56yo1_500.gif

There used to be only 4 total bans. It was increased to 6. There's no way you can sit there and tell us Riot couldn't have increased that to 10.

As for item sets, there is no excuse to not already have item sets working in the new client before it was forced onto everyone.

Their excuse was that they weren't going to reimplement them before the backlash made them reconsider.

I don't know why they'd bother scrapping them in the first place (since many of the default item recommendations suck), but they wanted to.

Their data showed that very few people actually used them, so it didn't seem worth it to keep them. However, they found out that a lot of people _do_ actually use them, they just don't need to use the creator often, so it seems as though it goes unused.

If that's the case, I can understand how their numbers were off.  I know many have an item set for each champ, but I'd be willing to bet many are like me.  Their items sets are more general to help them find what they want fast.  For example; I just have three sets "AD" "AP" and "support.  Then those are further sorted into the role/need each item serves.  "MR" "Armor" "Lifesteal" "Crit" and so on.  So I don't use the tool much at all because it's only used when items are changed so that they fit a different section, or new items are added (I.E. every mid and preseason update).  If that's how they got their numbers, then no wonder they were super low.
not to mention, making an item set was more of a one time thing, unless a new item came out or you needed to fix something, you didn't constantly come back to it.

This ^ that statement made no fucking sense. Like at all. It's just denying access which is a pretty damn low resource feature. The fact that the client can run the start up of the game animation and background music already indicates you can support banning every single champ available in every moba ever made on that old client.
The legacy client did SUPPORT 10 bans, but Riot did not want to implement it because there was no point. Why spend time implementing 10 bans when it will be retired in a few months anyway?

But it's ok because the new client is awesome.

They can't even add a dedicated announcer to a game mode properly and we have to suffer the Dark Star one in SR.

Riot making leaps and bounds, lol.
You don't have to "suffer" anything when the announcer is 100% optional and you can disable it whenever you want. Oh wait you are here just to complain about something that doesn't even exist.

......*sigh*

If you don't like it you can just click the little box to disable it.

Not like I wasn't doing that already.
no, I meant "have some respect and understanding for riot."  A game like this takes alot more into consideration than you or I would think.
I have a job, I know how "the chain of command" works.

What Riot has stated in the past about the legacy client, is mostly that is was a huge pain in the ass to code for, and often many new features only caused more things to break, causing more issues and resources. This is one of the main reasons they chose to make the new client in the first place.

Close, but you are still missing the point.

The new client has been in development for how long?
Why do they only now, after making it mandatory for everybody, starting to think about implementing 10 bans?
Why couldn't they simply not "release" it at this moment and add this feature, especially since there are still ongoing performance problems with the new client?
Why it was released without adding all features community wanted and Riot agreed on, if they can suddenly do it in a matter of a month or two?

I mean postponing the release of a new GAME could have serious consequences, but for all intends and purposes this is just a mundane patch. Why so hell-bent on going through with it?
